qas.question: What system deemed non-Muslims subjects of the empire but unbound by Muslim law?
What code had been active for 900 years in the Byzantine empire?
What were non-Muslims also known as in the Islamic Ottoman State?
Being a non-muslim in the Empire resulted in what as it related to taxes?
What millet was subject to Justinian's Code?

context: Under <a0_0>the millet system<a0_0/>, non-Muslim people were considered subjects of the Empire, but were not subject to the Muslim faith or Muslim law. <a4_0>The Orthodox millet<a4_0/>, for instance, was still officially legally subject to <a1_0>Justinian's Code<a1_0/>, which had been in effect in the Byzantine Empire for 900 years. Also, as the largest group of non-Muslim subjects (or <a2_0>zimmi<a2_0/>) of the Islamic Ottoman state, the Orthodox millet was granted a number of special privileges in the fields of politics and commerce, and had to pay <a3_0>higher taxes<a3_0/> than Muslim subjects.
